titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, United States Internatioanal Affairs Program (USIAP), Education and Culture, Correspondence of Edward J. Meade
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, United States Internatioanal Affairs Program (USIAP), Education and Culture, Correspondence of Edward J. Meade FA600

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-25 00:23:27 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, United States International Affairs Program (USIAP), Education and Culture, Correspondence of Edward J. Meade

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Level 1 Minimal Processing has been conducted to establish basic intellectual and physical control of the material and assess immediate preservation and conservation needs. Material remains as received, in original folders and storage boxes.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edward Meade worked at the Ford Foundation for almost 30 years. He predominantly worked in the Foundation's education programs. From the mid-1960s to the mid-1970s, he led the Division of Education and Research, Public Education Program as Officer in Charge. Following a reorganization of the Foundation's programming, he became Chief Program Officer of the United States and International Affairs (USIAP), Urban Poverty Program. Meade then moved to the USIAP, Education and Culture Program as Chief Program Officer.
